body.p:
Your mms. came safe to hand. not having entire
confidence in my own opinions upon the merits of your work, I deemed it
much more to your interest to forwarded to Mr. Etting (a man high in society
and fully competent to judge whether the work ought to be farther revised
and corrected, as by a single remark in your letter I suspect it does. Mr Mordecai
ought never to have permitted it to pass from his hands without having it in
every shape alike honorable to yourself and to the public hence he ought to
have pointed out all its errors to you which he had remarked to Mr. Peioxato-
It is a work of too much importance to be lightly cast off and put to pass-
and believe me your reputation will sink or swim by its success. Therefore
be not to precipitate in your writes to have it published till you are thoroughly
convinced by the decisions of others competent to decide upon its merits that
honor and profit is to be the result. Where I in your place I would solicit
every investigation and leave not a loop to hang a doubt upon for criticism
either in style spelling or punctuation, but let every thing bear you forward.
These remarks are in the truest spirit of friendship, for I am looking always
forward and never satisfied with the present. So shall I look towards you.
I hope to see you take a high and honorable stand in the literary world for
yourself and our society. I fear also that your ambition and the warmth of
your friends will make you o'er leap the bounds of prudence. A stability of
character is wanting Isaac in all men who come before the public and
this world is more apt to judge harshly than favorable of us. I am never
? for repassing? the vigilance and perseverance of youthful ambitions, go on
to the very summit, but each step must improve as you progress—let but
the basement be punishment you bring so you have every thing to expect.

I shall take occasion on Sunday next to go out to Mr. Etting he will then
have got so far into the work as to give some opinion upon it be it what it may
favorable or otherways. I shall feel it my duty to express it to you in the most liberal
manner, for having accepted of my duties to aid you thro this business and “leaving
you to act as I think best” I am decidedly of opinion that this shall be no
hurry off matters. ? of so much importance. If the course which
I suggest is not compatable to your wishes, say so, and I will forward it to Philad-
to Mr. Piexotto or return it to you without taking any farther interest then being
permitted to subscribe for a few copies. For altho I have been crooked in my
affairs generally, much of that was the result of friends and friendly advise. Seldom
when I think on serious matters that I am not correct in my views, therefore
Isaac draw your attention to that rock which many have split upon.

I shall now rest till Mr. Etting has gotten through with the work, then I shall
over look it myself, and, as far as I can, so will I express myself to you. I shall
be absent about three weeks but the nos shall be kept safe in my absence
and nothing shall go contrary to your desires in any arrangmt. which I may
make with the publishers.
